awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF-RM: Collaborative Research: Future of Construction Work at the Human-Technology Frontier
awd_abstract_narration:
The construction industry faces many workforce-related challenges, including a shortage of skilled workers and high accident and injury rates. The use of robotic technologies to augment construction workers can enable new construction techniques and work opportunities. This project seeks to transform the nature of construction work by removing barriers to the formation of human-robot teams on the jobsite. Working together with skilled trade workers, robots have the potential to lower construction costs through more precise cutting and placing actions that reduce waste. Human-robot teams can also increase safety and efficiency by reducing the risk of overexertion and injury to workers. The investigators will address three specific barriers to the widespread adoption of robotics on the construction site: (1) the lack of clearly defined and fully structured robotic tasks for trade work; (2) the need to understand how robots will be integrated into predominantly human-centric trade worker teams; and (3) the need to identify new knowledge and resource requirements that will support robots on the construction jobsite. 

This project explores convergent solutions to overcoming barriers to human-robot teaming in construction, using methods from computer science, construction engineering, and social science to: (a) re-define construction tasks by translating the means and methods of trade work into common actions that can be interpreted and performed by robotic systems, and (b) explore how robotic systems can be integrated into current and future human-robot construction teams, as an integral part of the worker, knowledge, task, and resource networks on the jobsite. To achieve these aims, this research will surface which construction tasks can and cannot be automated or augmented using robotics. Of the processes that are well-suited to robotics, basic design information will be converted into defined tasks and ultimately into instructions for the robot and the conditions needed to perform the action. Shared mental models for introducing robots within trade worker teams will be created, which will assist in determining the role of human-made robotic systems, as either active team participants or simply passive tools. Lastly, a meta-network analysis will study the potential vulnerability of human-robot teams to identify the risks and opportunities for improving the reliability of construction project delivery. These efforts will result in a risk framework for understanding the direct (e.g., safety) and indirect (e.g., network vulnerabilities) risks, as well as unintended consequences, emerging from the integration of robots in the construction work context. Collectively, this research will advance the potential for human-robot teams in the construction industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Industrialized and Robotic Construction Site (IRoCS) project addressed three key challenges: defining robotic tasks and capabilities in construction, integrating robots with human teams, and modeling the evolving network of construction projects to understand robots' impact on overall performance.

Defining and structuring robotic construction work tasks: With the increasing number of on-site construction robots, planners need to understand a wide array of information about robots to deploy them effectively. To meet this need, industry subject matter experts and construction robot developers were engaged to develop  the Construction Robot Schema (CRS), a database of useful robot attributes . The resulting CRS has four categories and 56 attributes; the categories address the physical properties of the robotic platform and manipulator, operational requirements, such as power requirements or spatial needs, construction activity performance to support production planning and scheduling, and safety requirements and features.  CRS provides information to support construction project planners deploying a robot to construction tasks and processes. 

Construction planners can leverage CRS to collect and compare data for emerging robots based on observation and measurement during operation or can request information from the developer or previous users for better understanding and comparisons with similar robots before deployment or operation around the human workforce in dynamic construction projects. To further illustrate and support access to robotic information we developed a construction robot wiki to capture current and emerging construction robots with public information in the format of CRS. The Construction Robotics Wiki (https://sites.psu.edu/constructionrobotics/) provides a platform to share construction robots’ information with stakeholders and to exchange experiences with robots which can promote development and on-site operation. 

Integrating robots with a predominantly human workforce: A framework of human-robot team cognition was developed, based on interviews and onsite observations, particularly in the construction industry with examples like SAM (Semi-Autonomous Mason), Dusty, and Jaibot. The framework  merges mental models held by humans and those held by robots. The framework focuses on accuracy, the timeliness of internal updating of the model by people and by robots, and across the team, the sharedness of the model for the multiple members that could make up this team within a construction crew. For accuracy, when humans learn to work with robots, the framework ensures team members understand robot capabilities correctly to avoid misuse or underutilization. The updating of the framework needs to consider both the physical tasks workers are engaged in as well as their cognitive load in planning their work and monitoring the robot and developing sharedness of how the model addresses both the human and robot roles in the process and procedures for sharing information in a dynamic setting. In turn, the robot needs to be able to respond to varied perceptions and interactions with different human co-workers, continuously update contextual information to support safe operations, and align the shared information flow to adapt to the changing status of work, evolving construction site context, and movement or feedback from the human co-workers. When studying the framework, the most successful teams featured humans open to change and new technology but also worked with the robots as independent actors and collaborators.

Modeling the vulnerability of industrialized construction processes: Industrialized construction processes, like manual construction processes, are vulnerable to disruption by adverse events. By modeling construction as a network of interconnected tasks, resources, and roles,  the impact of adverse events like power outages, operator errors, or material shortages were simulated. Findings revealed that critical roles and resources significantly influence the success of human-robot collaboration. Certain combinations of adverse events can leave 16% to 25% of tasks unfinished, with worst-case scenarios causing up to 67% of tasks to remain incomplete.

The results highlight the need for robust planning and contingency strategies when integrating robots into construction workflows. Project managers can prioritize critical roles, ensure backup plans, and improve team coordination to minimize disruptions. For educators, the study emphasizes the importance of teaching future professionals about the complexities of industrialized construction, including managing disruptions, balancing workloads, and building trust between humans and robots. This knowledge is crucial as automation becomes more prevalent in construction.

Understanding vulnerability in industrialized construction is vital because construction projects are highly interdependent. A single disruption can cause delays and cost overruns. By identifying critical nodes and simulating potential failures, this research helps teams prepare for uncertainties, improving project resilience and efficiency. Practical implications include better risk management, smoother project execution, and enhanced training programs for future professionals. This research provides a roadmap for building more resilient construction teams, ensuring smoother project execution in an era of increasing automation.
